awd_titl_txt: Using Collective Argumentation to Develop Teaching Practices Integrating Coding Within the Science and Math Curriculum (Grades 3-5)
awd_abstract_narration:
As computing has become integral to the practice of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), the STEM + Computing Program seeks to study and advance the applied integration of computational thinking and computing activities within disciplinary STEM teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school (preK-12). Elementary school teachers have a great impact on student motivation to pursue STEM fields of study and careers and are being increasingly asked to emphasize key STEM content, including  computer science in their teaching. However, few of these teachers have the academic background to achieve these expectations. This three-year STEM+C project will develop a practice that elementary school teachers can use to integrate the teaching of coding with the standard practices already used to teach mathematics, science and other curriculum content. The project also will develop a model course that prepares teachers to educate students in interdisciplinary, holistic ways to learn mathematics, science, and coding and equips them to guide students through reasoning processes while learning to code. Outcomes will inform the fields of computer science, mathematics, and science education about an argumentation-based approach that integrates the teaching of STEM, a core objective of the STEM+C program. 

This project aims to increase attention to computer science coding in elementary classrooms and the probability that elementary students develop interests in coding and other STEM-focused areas of study. To do so, the project will create (a) a learning approach in which novice programmers (i.e., elementary teachers and students) use arguments to develop a coding sequence using structured reasoning instead of trial-and-error, (b) help teachers build content knowledge of programming and extend their knowledge of appropriate mathematics and science pedagogy into the teaching of coding through argumentation, and (c) emphasize the argumentation approach as an integrator for the teaching and learning of coding, mathematics, and science. Activities associated with this project will enhance teachers' understanding of argumentation and then investigate how the teachers implement the CALC approach in grades 3 to 5. Participating teachers will enroll in a graduate-level course that teaches them how to use the CALC approach for coding. Once the teachers complete the course, they will implement the CALC approach in their classroom, helping their students to learn how to code. The research team will coach the teachers in their lesson enactments and will assess the effectiveness of the CALC concept as an age-appropriate method to teach and learn computer science content. Assessment data include capturing teacher actions via video recordings that will be analyzed in an ongoing process, interviews of teachers and assessment of student work.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the Collective Argumentation Learning and Coding (CALC) framework as an approach for integrating the teaching of computer coding into the standard practices used in the elementary school curriculum. This framework reaches beyond the content area of computer coding; it is constructed around collective argumentation, a learning approach valuable to building students' knowledge in mathematics, science, and many other disciplines. CALC equips elementary school teachers to include coding in their regular classroom instruction so all school students, not just those who enroll in after-school or enrichment programs, learn computer coding.  The result will be the preparation of a more diverse set of students for middle and high school computer science courses.  The outcomes of this project inform the fields of computer science, mathematics, and science education of the process to improve students’ abilities to create and critique arguments and make better decisions within the context of our increasingly technological and information-heavy world.

 

One objective was to design a course that focuses on the principles of collective argumentation to teach coding through appropriate reasoning, making coding relevant to learning practices already in elementary school standards. Teaching coding using the CALC framework has several benefits. First, CALC promotes a more structured approach to learning coding where students make their reasoning for developing a particular coding structure public and move away from trying to learn coding using unsystematic trial-and-error. Second, CALC allows teachers to use methods already in use in mathematics and science instruction, thus increasing the probability that it is taught as a regular part of classroom instruction. Over 30 elementary school teachers from one district participated in our prototype CALC course. We found evidence that course activities increased teachers’ coding knowledge of sequential and repetition control structures for producing efficient code. During interviews, almost all expressed beliefs that coding was an important subject for students to learn, that their students could learn how to code, and that course material increased their knowledge of how to teach coding. This website provides course materials and instructor facilitation guides:

 https://coe.uga.edu/research/labs/the-collective-argumentation-and-learning-coding-calc-project/

 

During a CALC-related task, students engage in arguments where they make a claim that something is true, use evidence (e.g., data, principles) to support that claim and generate the reasoning that logically connects the evidence to the claim. Teachers must appropriately support students during argumentation, making teacher supportive actions a critical element of the CALC framework. These supportive actions could be in the form of questions or other actions (e.g., directing students to do something). So, understanding what teacher supportive actions look like and how those actions support students engaged in argumentative learning is significant. Project activities were designed to assess how teachers use the CALC framework to support their students' mathematics, science, and coding learning.

 

The team followed ten teachers as they implemented the CALC framework in elementary school classrooms, integrating coding and robotics into mathematics, science, social studies, and literacy instruction. Over 100 hours of videos of CALC-related activities were examined. Almost 55% of teacher support was in the form of questions, resulting in the student providing a factual answer or elaborating on an explanation. The team also investigated the warrants teachers and students generated during CALC-related tasks. Warrants are the reasoning used to link evidence to a claim during an argument, and knowledge about warrants is useful when preparing teachers to engage their students in productive arguments that integrate mathematics, science, and coding content. The identified warrants were categorized into three groups: a) explicit (i.e., either written down or verbally expressed), b) implicit (i.e., one that is not explicitly stated), or c) hybrid.   Almost 60% of the student-generated warrants were explicit. The warrants were also categorized by contexts (mathematics, coding, integrated), and the distributions of these categories were analyzed. The highest percentage of warrants generated during coding and integrated context involved activities such as the student inspecting the action of an entity (e.g., a robot's movement).   The highest percentage of warrants in mathematics included activities where a student performed a calculation,  recognized a pattern, employed a method, and similar activities. Knowledge of the types of supports teachers use during CALC-related tasks and what type of reasoning these supports generate can be used as guides that help teachers develop lessons that transition coding into regular classroom content.

 

This project generated materials for a professional development course (available online) and provided insights into how teachers support collective argumentation in integrated settings. These and other project outcomes will inform the fields of computer science, mathematics, and science education about an argumentation-based approach that integrates different STEM content areas and educates students in interdisciplinary, holistic ways to learn mathematics, science, and coding.
